Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation of US-based researchers in the China-US Group Theory Summit 2019 held at Texas State University in San Marcos, TX, on August 22-25, 2019. Group theory is a branch of modern algebra studying the notion of symmetry. It is a fundamental and highly active field of research within the mathematical sciences and has ramifications throughout all of mathematics and the sciences. There are large communities of group theory researchers in all continents, and they keep in touch through international meetings and conferences. However, local conditions and cultural circumstances under which mathematical research is done differ quite a bit between different regions of the world. The focus of this proposal is on research in group theory in the USA and in China. One major goal of the conference is to establish and strengthen ties between group theorists in China and the USA. It is the first conference in group theory with this focus.

The conference will provide group theory researchers in China and the USA a forum to disseminate their own research as well as to learn about new and significant results in the area. It will help to bridge the gap between the group theory communities in the United States and China, and lead to future cooperation and collaborations. Speakers from both countries will cover a large variety of the subjects in the area, which include representations of solvable groups, representations of simple groups, character theory, classes of groups, groups and combinatorics, p-groups, and fusion systems. There will be about fifteen invited talks and a limited number of contributed talks. The conference will provide an inviting atmosphere to foster new collaborations; young researchers will have the opportunity to present their work and learn about the latest developments in the field. It is expected that it will have a great impact on the math research communities in both countries. More information about the conference can be found at https://www.math.txstate.edu/research-conferences/gtsummit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference China-US Group Theory Summit 2019 was held at Texas State University in San Marcos, TX on August 22-25, 2019. This was the first conference of its kind and is expected to be followed by similar meetings in the future, to be held alternately in China and the United States. The purpose of the meeting was to facilitate interactions between mathematicians from China and the United States, with interests in group and representation theory, broadly interpreted.

Participants met at Texas State University for plenary talks, short talks in parallel sessions, and mathematical discussions. There were seven main speakers (who gave the plenary talks) from each the US and China, and there were 19 short talks given in two parallel sessions with two talks at a time. The seven main speakers from the US were Daniel Allcock (University of Texas at Austin), George Glauberman (University of Chicago), Luise-Charlotte Kappe (Binghamton University), Mark Lewis (Kent State University), Hung Nguyen (University of Akron),  Alexandre Turull (University of Florida),  Ryan Vinroot (William and Mary), and the seven main speakers from China were Lijian An (Shangxi Normal University), Xiuyun Guo (Shanghai University), Ping Jin (Shangxi University,  Guohua Qian (Changshu Institute of Technology),  Baoshan Wang  (Beihang University),  Lizhong Wang (Peking University),  Fei Xu (Shantou University). Topics covered by the talks included permutation groups, finite p-groups, fusion systems, finite coverings, character theory, factorizations of groups, products of subgroups, algebraic groups, local/global conjectures in representation theory, Frobenius groups and many more. Most talks were accessible and appealing to a broad range of mathematicians. 

The total attendance was about 60. Participants came from all over the US and China. The participants included faculty at all career stages and from different types of institutions. Most of the NSF support was used for travel and lodging for US participants with limited access to travel funds.

The conference provided group theory researchers from China and the USA a forum to disseminate their own research as well as to learn about new and significant results in the area, which led to a 2-way transfer of knowledge. The conference helped to bridge the gap between those two communities, which is expected to lead to future cooperation and collaborations. This will have significant impact on the mathematics research communities in both countries. For several Chinese participant this was their very first visit to the United States, and the meeting provided them a unique opportunity to get to know their American colleagues whose papers they have read in the past. Also, the US mathematicians got to meet many people from China for the first time. Several common meals provided by the conference supported the interaction between participants. One outcome of these interactions was that some participants made plans for future visits of the other country. We anticipate that these connections will help them in their academic pursuits.
